page.title: 01Location of Dean
page.content: Dean is Bedfordshire's most northerly village and one of the most attractive. The Parish stretches from the Melchbourne boundary to the Three Shires Stone on the A45, marking the junction of Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire: the original stone was the base of an old stone cross. Dean straddles a small tributary of the River Till: there is a ford across Shay Lane. The village is in 2 parts Upper and Lower Dean which are separated by about 0.5 mile of winding lanes. Overlooking the villages from Shelton Hill is a windmill, now a derelict tower mill with some of it's machinery and sails still in place. It is the last of such mills in North Bedfordshire and would be well worth saving. From the road between Upper and Lower Dean a wide Green Lane leads to walks.
